text: hello good morning or afternoon or evening wherever your day finds you and welcome to the amazon web services
partner webinar series our topic today will feature enterprise document management and collaboration on aws i'm
your host sherry sullivan i'm with the partner marketing team here in seattle and i'd like to remind folks that um we
are recording today's webinar and while your lines are muted we do invite you to submit questions anytime during this
webcast and we'll take a few moments at the end to answer those questions i'd also like to remind folks that
we do make our content available on aws youtube channel as well as slideshare
and you will receive a link to this on-demand recording i'm pleased to be joined today by louis
falca who is the director of technology alliances at alfresco which is one of
our technology partners along with alfresco's customer steve clements who's
the director of development at united cerebral palsy of greater chicago and i also have ryan holland here with
me who is the ecosystem solution architect with amazon web services
we'll begin with just an overview today of amazon web services and cloud formation
automating deployments and we'll be followed with um an overview of learning how
the ucp leveraged alfresco solutions to get control of their content management
and then we'll close out with some of the benefits of content management solutions with albresco
so we'll wrap up as i said with a few moments of q a and with that i'd like to introduce ryan holland please take it
away ryan thank you very much charity and thank you everyone for joining us today so i just want to start off with you
know what is aws or amazon web services and and one of the things i find when people are new to aws is they tend to be
a little bit surprised just how many services we have a lot of people are familiar with things like ec2 or s3 but aws actually spans 25
different services that range from networking services our core compute
storage and database services but also some very important application services
as well as deployment services and and all of these are hosted inside our global infrastructure
and allows customers to use those without having to build out any of their own facilities or infrastructure and run
their applications on top of that platform so i mentioned it's a it's a global
infrastructure and as you can see we we span five different continents with our data centers
and we have nine different regions in these in these five continents and for us a region is actually a
cluster of highly redundant data centers that customers can leverage for deploying their applications and their
data and this is a continuously expanding global footprint and as we continue to
add capacity and additional regions to meet the needs of our customers you'll see this grow over time
so why are customers choosing to deploy their applications on aws you know a lot
of times people really start with the first two items on this slide you know leveraging our economies of scale and
being able to trade their capital expenses for operational expenses and being able to
save money is great and once people get past that though they start looking at and they start appreciating even more
the additional flexibility that you have with aws that doesn't come with traditional infrastructure
so you're able to get to market very quickly you're able to deploy a new application or a new service or start a
new project and you're able to do that without having to procure or rack and stack a whole bunch of hardware
and you also have a lot of flexibility in that if that project doesn't end up working out or you want to try something
different you're not locked into a three-year depreciation cycle on on a host of pieces of hardware you can
simply turn those services off and then stop paying for them and you're able to again
leverage our global infrastructure so you can deploy replicas of your application or reach
markets where it might not be cost effective for you to deploy a second set of your own physical infrastructure
and lastly you don't have to guess on capacity and we'll cover that here in just a second when i i show you a sample
alfresco deployment that i've used on aws where you're able to grow and shrink the size
of your deployment based on your needs so so as i said here's a sample alfresco
deployment that i've created on aws and it uses quite a number of our different
services so from starters all of this is deployed in amazon virtual private cloud or vpc
which is a logically isolated set of infrastructure that customers can
can use and control all sorts of networking aspects from ip space to the
subnets that they use and it's completely logically isolated from all other resources
i'm also using our elastic load balancer to direct traffic across multiple availability zones so i wanted this to
be a highly available deployment and so my load balancer will move the track will direct the traffic um to the
different uh availability zones that i've deployed in i've used ec2 and auto scaling for my
alfresco cluster so i've created a cluster of alfresco servers that are sitting behind my load balancer and by
leveraging our auto scaling service that cluster can grow to support from 10 users to 10 000 users and i don't have
to change anything on my deployment it's all automatic and as my load changes my
infrastructure is going to adapt with it and grow or shrink based on the needs of my application
and then for storage of all of my alfresco objects we're leveraging amazon s3 amazon s3 is really a great storage
choice for alfresco for one it has 11 9's of durability
which means you don't have to worry about backing up all of that data and if you remember when i talked about not
needing to to figure out pre-size your environment the amazon s3 allows you to store
objects from ranging from size of one byte to five terabytes in size and you can store
an unlimited quantity of objects so because i'm leveraging that for my shared storage i don't have to think
about how big is this deployment going to be from a storage aspect in one year or in
three years and over buy or possibly under buy my back-end storage system
i only have to pay for the storage that i'm actually consuming and i can consume an endless quantity of that based on my
needs and then lastly for the database that alfresco leverages uh not being a dba
myself i didn't really want to have to deal with managing and setting up a database so i leveraged our rds or
relational database service for mysql and what this allows me to do is have
the entire database tier managed by aws and it's done so in a multi-az or so a
multi-data center fashion which means all of my data is replicated across two physical data centers
i'm presented with a single dns name and aws handles any kind of failover should
your master database have an issue it also handles performing all of the database backups at the schedule i
choose and it will also
and so there's quite a number of components that you can see there and one of the really other interesting things is i can deploy this entire
system in about 20 minutes and it's not because i'm a fast typer
it's because of another service that we have called cloud formation which allows me to
automate a deployment of aws resources using a consistent scripting interface
so if we look at what is a cloud formation deployment it starts with the template and the cloud
formation template is a json formatted file so it's plain text which is nice it
means i can check that into a source control and i can use that to do change control on my
infrastructure and that that template is passed into the cloud formation service
which will create that stack of resources it also is the service i can use to update those those resources
later on and then what comes out of that is we call the stack or the confirmation stack
which is that entire collection of resources that i defined in that
template and it's ready for use there's a couple
features of the template that are that are really important to understand the first one is its parameters
that you can use so you don't want to create a template that's only specific for me right i want something that can
be used by other people or that maybe i can leverage in other regions as well
and so we want to be able to take in different parameters so the example we're showing here is which ssh key
should we put on all of the instances so you can enable ssh access which is extremely common
but i also could parameterize for example what size do i want my alfresco instances to be do i want them to start
out as m1 larges or m1 smalls so you can pick that and make that a parameter so customers can fill that in
on their own and then it also contains the set of resources that you want it to
define so for example on the screen here you can see the rds component so this is how
we do we create a a resource in aws so every single
resource that was on that architecture diagram was defined in this manner using a json format
and then i can also customize those by defining different actions that i want
it to take as well so as you can see here i've said okay once you start this instance i want to run the i want you to
install a set of packages where i want you to source a set of files from s3 and install different applications and this
allows me to then customize and configure those resources once this started up
so this this gives us a way to programmatically define our infrastructure and define all of our
assets that are in there in a programmatic fashion i can collaborate with other co-workers by using source
control things like github to check in this template and share it with others and i know that every time this template
is ran i'm going to have a known and consistent output and that's really important and then i'm allowed to again
use parameters to customize that for future runs
and so now with that i want to hand over to luis from alfresco thank you very much ryan and thank you
cherie for hosting us so my name is luis sala and i'm alfresco's director of technology alliances alfresco
we like to describe ourselves as the open platform for business critical content management and collaboration so
let's parse that for a moment by open platform alfresco first and foremost is at its core an
open source uh platform and we offer a wide variety of
different apis that conform to open standards such as content management interpret
interoperability services on top of that many of our customers and partners si partners use alfresco as an underlying
repository for their content-centric applications giving them the ability to
use content in ways that are contextual to their business critical processes
in addition to all that alfresco is inherently collaborative in nature allowing you to collaborate with
colleagues on projects and and be able to achieve
measurable business results alfresco is also
used for wide variety of different use cases some of the high level use cases include file sharing and team collaboration
document management which includes managing the metadata around the documents so the information that
describes these documents and and distinguishes say a purchase order from a contract and from a from an invoice
we support records management and compliance so these are things that support things like that
requirements such as retention of documents for compliance reasons uh as well as defining other types of policies
so for example legal holds which might be applicable in the event of litigation
or something along those lines so all this together gives you sarbanes-oxley style compliance and
alfresco also has been certified against the department of defense 50 15 and up to
requirements digital asset management is a common use case also that's used for alfresco so alfresco handles multimedia
very nicely and and we'll see a little bit about this in the
in the upcoming customer testimonial searchable archives are a popular use case especially amongst academia and
and cultural organizations so for example the martin luther king foundation
uses alfresco as the repository for storing the with the works of martin luther king
and the new york philharmonic uh uses alfresco as well for uh for storing um
and archiving a lot of their their performances musical scores annotations
and so forth and finally alfresco is used for web content publishing types of scenarios so we have uh
we power a lot of websites such as fox fox.com and and sony pictures
entertainment alfresco has been around for over seven
years and collectively across the different installations of alfresco where we've got over four billion files
under management a user base in excess of 7 million across 3 000 um enterprise customers
distributed across 180 countries alfresco is designed to be
scalable and a lot of what we've done here with amazon web services is capture
our br best practices for deploying a scalable robust fault tolerant
environment and in in a way that can be easily deployed by any customer on amazon web
services and that's what ryan's conversation about using cloudformation comes into play
we've captured all these best practices into a simple cloud formation template that allows you to deploy a scalable
cluster in approximately 20 minutes and this is something that's uh from a business acceleration
perspective and so forth so what that basically means is that we've got customers with uh that are
managing over a hundred thousand excuse me 100 million documents with a user base in excess of
a hundred thousand users and ingesting in excess of ten thousand documents per day so alfresco is just
very high performance very scalable we're also very integratable alfresco
has been created into a wide variety of different products and suites we support for example uh the full microsoft office
stack we have mobile applications that integrate with other mobile applications to allow you to be productive in a
tablet oriented environment we integrate with google docs we can publish information to social channels
allowing you to centrally manage your information and disseminate it in a wide variety of ways
now uh at its core alfresco offers a wide variety of features and what i'd like you to do is just focus on the section
in orange which summarizes some of the key features that any content repository needs to support and certainly alfresco
is capable of and i'll just highlight the top three there version control custom metadata indexing and search

but we can discuss those perhaps doing question and answer and by the way i do encourage you to use the q a panel to

the customer the ucp customer use case and that's where we're going to hand it off to

they're doing it um for development of
students and adults with disabilities steve take it away well thanks so much and uh thanks for

and aws both have been excellent partners for united cerebral palsy
i'm going to be sharing really two use cases with you we are using alfresco as both the web content

aspect of our program so what i'd like to do today over the next few minutes is give you a just a
very brief overview of who we are united cerebral palsy and then specifically
a program of ours called infinitetech which is a really content heavy program and really has driven us to these to
these choices i'll spend a couple of minutes talking about sort of the legacy choices and some of
the pain that came along with those legacy choices and how that pain really pushed us to kind of set a new
technology direction that involved both alfresco and aws i'll give you an overview of the
architecture of our two use cases and do a very quick demo so you can see how this all looks
uh from an end user standpoint and then i'll wrap up spending a couple of minutes talking about
why we chose each of these two vendor offerings and what benefits we've
derived from those offerings so just a brief little bit about united
cerebral palsy many of you here in the u.s have probably heard of united cerebral palsy it's a national organization with local sort of chapters
or franchises and we are united cerebral palsy of greater chicago as is probably expected if you look at
our mission statement you know we're all about advancing the independence of folks with disabilities enriching their
lives and really advocating for inclusion in every facet of their life we as a as a
united cerebral palsy entity have been around since the early 50s and we run a wide variety of programs we
do everything from building ramps on people's houses to help them get in and out we run adult
programs for adults with disabilities and we serve you know birth to three and a huge
population of schools through a program that we call infinitec and so infinitetech is one of
our programs we have many and infinitetech was started because our ceo came from the k-12 educational world
and he decided for us that one of the best ways we could impact the
lives of people with disabilities is to work with schools to make sure that while that child with a disability is in
school that they maximize that experience and we use you know our focus is how can how
can we help schools do a better job using technology to improve the lives of students with disabilities
there's no question that technology when applied properly in the classroom can be an absolute game changer
for a student with a disability and and it's not all high-tech technology i provided a few pictures here to kind of
give you a view of the breadth of technology it can be very simple things like a pencil grip that that can help a
child you know who has a hand issue or a mobility issue it can be an easel to make the work surface more
appropriate for a particular student with a physical disability there's no question that ipads have changed the
world of education both for normally abled students as well as students with disabilities for students
without voices or the ability to speak augmentative communication devices like
the one pictured there offer voice to people who've never had a voice before it's just amazing and then the
last example over on the right one of the more complex systems for someone with a physical disability
you know you we often see eye gaze systems that literally track the position of the student's eyeballs and
allow them to navigate uh a pointer on a screen and make selections uh through the use of their eyes so an
amazing breath of technology and those are just five simple examples there are literally
tens of thousands of different pieces of technology that can be deployed in a classroom
to help a student overcome a disability the interesting thing about this is that schools are here in the u.s anyhow are
literally required by law to provide the assistive technology that's deemed to be
required for the student to be success to be successful and schools really struggle with this
they struggle with integrating the piece of technology into the student's life they struggle with
getting the support staff to understand how to use that technology with the student they unders they struggle with
integrating the technology into the classroom and then lastly they struggle with integrating the technology into the
curriculum all very big complicated issues and you know for schools that are struggling
with budgets focus and time you think about all the initiatives going on in schools the
local expertise it requires that has to understand the technology and understand how to tackle the challenges and then
finally the fact that there are really a lack of best practices for for many of these things so it's a real struggle for
schools today and that's really where our program comes in you know we are all about
you know certain schools will have expertise in one area or another area so they all have crumbs they're all good
at little bits and pieces of this we pull these schools together into a co a membership based coalition
where we can collect the things that each of those schools are good at and turn those resources into a shared set
of resources that we can make available to all of our member schools via the web so we're a coalition of
school districts we're operating in five states here in the us today we're growing very quickly
we work with about 900 schools and today we impact about 1.6 million students through those schools so it's it's just
it's a huge program it's growing quickly we offer a variety of face-to-face
services but because we're growing and we're a small agency we rely very heavily on online services
so we crowdsource and internally create
tons of digital resources to help schools do a better job of providing access to the curriculum
to students with disabilities we do this primarily through a large web
portal called my infinitetech.org there are about 20 000 registered users
they're educational professionals everybody from teachers to school administrators to occupational
therapists physical therapists school psychologists lots of paraprofessionals
so lots of different profiles of users we have just under 300 different
professional development presentations we go out and we contract with the brightest and best
thought leaders in the field we create online learning
modules to help schools do a better job there are quizzes that go along with those so that educators can demonstrate
competency we host actually close to 2 000 different
resource documents each with links to the evidence that that backs up the uh
the particular um focus of of that resource you know schools are very focused on everything
needing to be evidence-based we've host lots of different lesson plans lots of resources on how to deploy
technology in the classroom and we also now have created using alfresco a
library of mobile apps to help schools do a better job of selecting which mobile apps they should
be deploying in their classroom on ipads and other mobile devices another component of the infinitech
program is a program called infinitext lots of students have disabilities that make it difficult for them to handle the
printed book they maybe have visual impairments they may have a physical disability that restricts their ability
to relate to a book or they may have learning disabilities so infinitex offers
access to the curriculum in scanned and digital formats there are about fifteen
thousand files that are stored within infinitex today each representing a piece of the curriculum
those pieces of the curriculum have been scanned and uploaded by school districts to participate in this program we offer
a very intuitive self-service website where they can come and download these
files for use with students with disabilities and we support multiple different formats
so very good application for document management
we'll talk about that a little later as we look at the architecture and demo it a little bit about the history
we're a not-for-profit charity so we tend to like to do things on the cheap we
started out with a home-grown platform for myinfinitec.org literally built by volunteers no content management all
static and literally i'm not lying we had servers in closets
so it was not a very good solution back in the early 2000 actually through most of the 2000s we migrated in 2009 to a
vendor platform again being a not for profit we tend to beg a bit and school wires was gifted to us
and we ran on that platform for about a year it was a hosted platform really designed for k to 12 schools if you have
a kid in school and that school has a website there's a pretty good chance that that website is powered by school
wires it really wasn't a good fit for us in addition it had limited content
management and again largely static html pages
those legacy platforms really created a number of pain points for the organization first of all i should
mention that you know technology management is not a core competency of a mid-sized social service agency
we tend to be very program focused and not very technology focused so we struggled with managing our own
technology it was a little better when we moved to school wires and that solution was hosted for us
but it was not ideal vendor's proprietary system lacked flexibility the school wires system was
built for school districts it didn't fit us really well there were registration issues we need to collect specific
information we couldn't extend that system we ran into lots of reporting issues
and content management has always been a problem for us we host a lot of different types of content we need to
integrate to one of the adobe products called adobe connect for our e-learning modules and learning
administration and the management of our content in general was just a very slow and costly
endeavor our content managers were not technical folks most of them were not even really familiar with html
it was difficult for them to post content on their own they needed to get technical resources involved and it was
a slow and arduous process for us the user experience was also not very good
the registration process was very cumbersome again because we needed to collect custom information that was not
supported and because it was all flat html there were many many many layers and levels of
pages that all of this flat content was organized on and we regularly heard feedback from our
user community that it was just too difficult to navigate and way too many clicks
i joined united cerebral palsy in 2008 about the time that our previous systems
were collapsing under their own weight and we knew we needed to do something differently we met a local systems integrator here
in chicago which i'll just put in a little plug for they're an amazing organization technology services group
we met them through a board member they are completely focused on enterprise content management they're
